overall_score_comment: Like actual espresso from a gas station — surprisingly addictive despite questionable ingredients.
the_roast:
Sabrina really said 'I'm going to make a song about being irresistible' and then rhymed 'espresso' with 'espresso' four thousand times like we wouldn't notice. That's the lyrical equivalent of ordering a venti and getting three shots of the same joke. The confidence is admirable, but girl, you're out here claiming 'My give-a-fucks are on vacation' while literally writing an entire song about how much this boy is obsessed with you. That's not indifference, that's a TED Talk.

Let's talk about the beverage brand massacre happening in the second verse. 'Mountain Dew it for ya'? 'Morning coffee, brewed it for ya'? 'Brand-newed it for ya'? This reads like a corporate sponsorship deal fell through at the last minute, so she just started freestyling every liquid and verb she could think of. I half expected 'I Gatorade it for ya, I marinated it for ya, I participated for ya.' The 'perfumed it for ya' line is the only one that makes sense, and even that sounds like she's describing a Yankee Candle.

And can we address 'Switch it up like Nintendo'? Bestie, are we talking about the console, the game, or are you just out here name-dropping childhood nostalgia hoping millennials will stream? Because moving 'up, down, left, right' sounds less like sexy choreography and more like you're teaching someone the Konami Code. The whole song is basically 'I'm so hot I keep him awake,' which is a great concept until you realize actual espresso also keeps people awake, and nobody writes love songs about their Nespresso machine. Oh wait.

cliche_counter.cliche: Being so attractive someone can't sleep
cliche_counter.quip: Insomnia as a flex — truly the romantic gesture of our melatonin-deficient generation

cliche_counter.cliche: The 'I don't care but also here's a whole song about it' paradox
cliche_counter.quip: Those give-a-fucks aren't on vacation, they're working overtime with a full benefits package
A metaphor so old it probably appeared in actual Shakespeare, but with less iambic pentameter
The ex slander is implied but omnipresent — we get it, you're an upgrade, you're basically the iPhone 15
Coffee metaphors in pop songs: because comparing yourself to cocaine would hurt streaming numbers

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: I know I Mountain Dew it for ya
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Verbing a soda brand name in a way that makes zero linguistic sense
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Mandatory songwriting class where you learn that not every noun can become a verb, especially trademarked ones

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: My honeybee, come and get this pollen
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Making pollination sound sexy, which is actually just describing seasonal allergies
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Forced to explain bird-and-bee metaphors to a panel of confused botanists

lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Grammatical chaos — is it 'that's me, espresso' or 'that's that me-espresso'? The syntax is having an existential crisis
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Diagramming this sentence on a whiteboard until it makes sense or you give up, whichever comes first

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Walked in and dream-came-trued it for ya
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Inventing the verb 'dream-came-trued' like English wasn't already suffering enough
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Reading the entire Strunk & White style guide aloud at a poetry slam while people throw dictionaries

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: I'm working late 'cause I'm a singer
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: The most unnecessary career clarification since 'I'm walking 'cause I have legs'
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Required to explain your job description in every social situation like you're filling out tax forms

hidden_meanings: Clearly this song is a profound meditation on late-stage capitalism's infiltration of romantic relationships, where human connection is commodified into brand-name beverages and gaming consoles. Either that, or Sabrina watched one too many TikToks about 'keeping him up at night' and decided caffeine addiction was the perfect metaphor for being hot. The jury's still out.
final_verdict: It's catchy enough that you'll hate yourself for singing 'that's that me espresso' in the shower for three weeks straight. The lyrics are 40% confidence, 30% beverage references, and 30% Nintendo product placement — which somehow adds up to a bop, but definitely not a Pulitzer.
title: Espresso
